Description: Fragment of terracotta figure of robed man with braided beard and turban-like headdress. Flat mould-made ‘Asiatic’, or ‘Assyrian’ man. Pressed into one-piece mould. Beard and details painted black. Heavy pale beige-white calcaric fabric with white inclusions. Features battered and worn; broken below shoulders.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ.(?) (likely)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Such ‘Asiatic’ looking male figurines date to between the mid 7th to late 6th centuries BC, with parallels from Cyprus (Karageorghis 1995, 19-21, Type I(ii)56-7). Karageorghis argues the ‘Assyrian’ look may coincide with Assyrian domination of Cyprus during the seventh century BC (1995, 21). See EA 50126, 50127, 50128, 50130 (EA 1911,0710.102, 1911,0710.103, 1911,0710.105) also from Naukratis. Context from register. A number of Cypriot terracotta and limestone figures were sent by the Egypt Exploration Fund in 1911 to the British Museum and various other museums including this one. Many of these were labelled T, Φ, or TAΦ, followed by a context number, designating these as coming from a context within the sanctuary of Aphrodite, from Gardner’s excavations in 1885-1886. This is also confirmed by British Museum and Boston MFA registers. This figure is from this group and so highly likely to have been excavated within the temenos of the Aphrodite sanctuary. Karageorghis, V. 1995. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. IV. The Cypro-Archaic Period small male figurines. Nicosia, Universityof Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.045) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
